trans-unit.source: PowerShell.exe Command Line Help
trans-unit.target: PowerShell.exe Command Line Help

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: PowerShell.exe Command-Line Help
trans-unit.target: PowerShell.exe Command-Line Help

trans-unit.source: Starts a Windows PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: Starts a Windows PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: You can use PowerShell.exe to start a Windows PowerShell session from the command line of another tool, such as Cmd.exe, or use it at the Windows PowerShell command line to start a new session.
trans-unit.target: You can use PowerShell.exe to start a Windows PowerShell session from the command line of another tool, such as Cmd.exe, or use it at the Windows PowerShell command line to start a new session.

trans-unit.source: Use the parameters to customize the session.
trans-unit.target: Use the parameters to customize the session.

trans-unit.source: Syntax
trans-unit.target: Syntax

trans-unit.source: Parameters
trans-unit.target: Parameters

trans-unit.source: -EncodedCommand <Base64EncodedCommand>
trans-unit.target: -EncodedCommand <Base64EncodedCommand>

trans-unit.source: Accepts a base-64-encoded string version of a command.
trans-unit.target: Accepts a base-64-encoded string version of a command.

trans-unit.source: Use this parameter to submit commands to Windows PowerShell that require complex quotation marks or curly braces.
trans-unit.target: Use this parameter to submit commands to Windows PowerShell that require complex quotation marks or curly braces.

trans-unit.source: -ExecutionPolicy <ExecutionPolicy>
trans-unit.target: -ExecutionPolicy <ExecutionPolicy>

trans-unit.source: Sets the default execution policy for the current session and saves it in the $env:PSExecutionPolicyPreference environment variable.
trans-unit.target: Sets the default execution policy for the current session and saves it in the $env:PSExecutionPolicyPreference environment variable.

trans-unit.source: This parameter does not change the Windows PowerShell execution policy that is set in the registry.
trans-unit.target: This parameter does not change the Windows PowerShell execution policy that is set in the registry.

trans-unit.source: For information about Windows PowerShell execution policies, including a list of valid values, see about_Execution_Policies (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135170).
trans-unit.target: For information about Windows PowerShell execution policies, including a list of valid values, see about_Execution_Policies (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135170).

trans-unit.source: -File <FilePath> \[<Parameters>]
trans-unit.target: -File <FilePath> \[<Parameters>]

trans-unit.source: Runs the specified script in the local scope ("dot-sourced"), so that the functions and variables that the script creates are available in the current session.
trans-unit.target: Runs the specified script in the local scope ("dot-sourced"), so that the functions and variables that the script creates are available in the current session.

trans-unit.source: Enter the script file path and any parameters.
trans-unit.target: Enter the script file path and any parameters.

trans-unit.source: **File** must be the last parameter in the command, because all characters typed after the **File** parameter name are interpreted as the script file path followed by the script parameters and their values.
trans-unit.target: **File** must be the last parameter in the command, because all characters typed after the **File** parameter name are interpreted as the script file path followed by the script parameters and their values.

trans-unit.source: You can include the parameters of a script, and parameter values, in the value of the **File** parameter.
trans-unit.target: You can include the parameters of a script, and parameter values, in the value of the **File** parameter.

trans-unit.source: For example: `-File .\Get-Script.ps1 -Domain Central`
trans-unit.target: For example: `-File .\Get-Script.ps1 -Domain Central`

trans-unit.source: Typically, the switch parameters of a script are either included or omitted.
trans-unit.target: Typically, the switch parameters of a script are either included or omitted.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command uses the **All** parameter of the Get-Script.ps1 script file: `-File .\Get-Script.ps1 -All`
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command uses the **All** parameter of the Get-Script.ps1 script file: `-File .\Get-Script.ps1 -All`

trans-unit.source: In rare cases, you might need to provide a Boolean value for a switch parameter.
trans-unit.target: In rare cases, you might need to provide a Boolean value for a switch parameter.

trans-unit.source: To provide a Boolean value for a switch parameter in the value of the **File** parameter, enclose the parameter name and value in curly braces, such as the following: `-File .\Get-Script.ps1 {-All:$False}`
trans-unit.target: To provide a Boolean value for a switch parameter in the value of the **File** parameter, enclose the parameter name and value in curly braces, such as the following: `-File .\Get-Script.ps1 {-All:$False}`

trans-unit.source: -InputFormat {Text | XML}
trans-unit.target: -InputFormat {Text | XML}

trans-unit.source: Describes the format of data sent to Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Describes the format of data sent to Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Valid values are "Text" (text strings) or "XML" (serialized CLIXML format).
trans-unit.target: Valid values are "Text" (text strings) or "XML" (serialized CLIXML format).

trans-unit.source: -Mta
trans-unit.target: -Mta

trans-unit.source: Starts Windows PowerShell using a multi-threaded apartment.
trans-unit.target: Starts Windows PowerShell using a multi-threaded apartment.

trans-unit.source: This parameter is introduced in Windows PowerShell 3.0.
trans-unit.target: This parameter is introduced in Windows PowerShell 3.0.

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell 3.0, single-threaded apartment (STA) is the default.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell 3.0, single-threaded apartment (STA) is the default.

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell 2.0, multi-threaded apartment (MTA) is the default.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell 2.0, multi-threaded apartment (MTA) is the default.

trans-unit.source: -NoExit
trans-unit.target: -NoExit

trans-unit.source: Does not exit after running startup commands.
trans-unit.target: Does not exit after running startup commands.

trans-unit.source: -NoLogo
trans-unit.target: -NoLogo

trans-unit.source: Hides the copyright banner at startup.
trans-unit.target: Hides the copyright banner at startup.

trans-unit.source: -NonInteractive
trans-unit.target: -NonInteractive

trans-unit.source: Does not present an interactive prompt to the user.
trans-unit.target: Does not present an interactive prompt to the user.

trans-unit.source: -NoProfile
trans-unit.target: -NoProfile

trans-unit.source: Does not load the Windows PowerShell profile.
trans-unit.target: Does not load the Windows PowerShell profile.

trans-unit.source: -OutputFormat {Text | XML}
trans-unit.target: -OutputFormat {Text | XML}

trans-unit.source: Determines how output from Windows PowerShell is formatted.
trans-unit.target: Determines how output from Windows PowerShell is formatted.

trans-unit.source: Valid values are "Text" (text strings) or "XML" (serialized CLIXML format).
trans-unit.target: Valid values are "Text" (text strings) or "XML" (serialized CLIXML format).

trans-unit.source: -PSConsoleFile <FilePath>
trans-unit.target: -PSConsoleFile <FilePath>

trans-unit.source: Loads the specified Windows PowerShell console file.
trans-unit.target: Loads the specified Windows PowerShell console file.

trans-unit.source: Enter the path and name of the console file.
trans-unit.target: Enter the path and name of the console file.

trans-unit.source: To create a console file, use the [Export-Console](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/4bab1c02-9e61-4aaf-9957-11d1934ef4ef) cmdlet in Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: To create a console file, use the [Export-Console](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/4bab1c02-9e61-4aaf-9957-11d1934ef4ef) cmdlet in Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: -Sta
trans-unit.target: -Sta

trans-unit.source: Starts Windows PowerShell using a single-threaded apartment.
trans-unit.target: Starts Windows PowerShell using a single-threaded apartment.

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell 3.0, single-threaded apartment (STA) is the default.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell 3.0, single-threaded apartment (STA) is the default.

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell 2.0, multi-threaded apartment (MTA) is the default.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell 2.0, multi-threaded apartment (MTA) is the default.

trans-unit.source: -Version <Windows PowerShell Version>
trans-unit.target: -Version <Windows PowerShell Version>

trans-unit.source: Starts the specified version of Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Starts the specified version of Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: The version that you specify must be installed on the system.
trans-unit.target: The version that you specify must be installed on the system.

trans-unit.source: If Windows PowerShell 3.0 is installed on the computer, valid values are "2.0" and "3.0".
trans-unit.target: If Windows PowerShell 3.0 is installed on the computer, valid values are "2.0" and "3.0".

trans-unit.source: The default value is "3.0".
trans-unit.target: The default value is "3.0".

trans-unit.source: If Windows PowerShell 3.0 is not installed, the only valid value is "2.0".
trans-unit.target: If Windows PowerShell 3.0 is not installed, the only valid value is "2.0".

trans-unit.source: Other values are ignored.
trans-unit.target: Other values are ignored.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see "Installing Windows PowerShell" in the [Getting Started with Windows PowerShell [OLD MSDN]](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/69555d95-b481-43e1-86e7-b46d68b3e2dd).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see "Installing Windows PowerShell" in the [Getting Started with Windows PowerShell [OLD MSDN]](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/69555d95-b481-43e1-86e7-b46d68b3e2dd).

trans-unit.source: -WindowStyle <Window style>
trans-unit.target: -WindowStyle <Window style>

trans-unit.source: Sets the window style for the session.
trans-unit.target: Sets the window style for the session.

trans-unit.source: Valid values are Normal, Minimized, Maximized and Hidden.
trans-unit.target: Valid values are Normal, Minimized, Maximized and Hidden.

trans-unit.source: -Command
trans-unit.target: -Command

trans-unit.source: Executes the specified commands (and any parameters) as though they were typed at the Windows PowerShell command prompt, and then exits, unless the NoExit parameter is specified.
trans-unit.target: Executes the specified commands (and any parameters) as though they were typed at the Windows PowerShell command prompt, and then exits, unless the NoExit parameter is specified.

trans-unit.source: The value of Command can be "-", a string.
trans-unit.target: The value of Command can be "-", a string.

trans-unit.source: or a script block.
trans-unit.target: or a script block.

trans-unit.source: If the value of Command is "-", the command text is read from standard input.
trans-unit.target: If the value of Command is "-", the command text is read from standard input.

trans-unit.source: Script blocks must be enclosed in braces ({}).
trans-unit.target: Script blocks must be enclosed in braces ({}).

trans-unit.source: You can specify a script block only when running PowerShell.exe in Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You can specify a script block only when running PowerShell.exe in Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: The results of the script are returned to the parent shell as deserialized XML objects, not live objects.
trans-unit.target: The results of the script are returned to the parent shell as deserialized XML objects, not live objects.

trans-unit.source: If the value of Command is a string, **Command** must be the last parameter in the command , because any characters typed after the command are interpreted as the command arguments.
trans-unit.target: If the value of Command is a string, **Command** must be the last parameter in the command , because any characters typed after the command are interpreted as the command arguments.

trans-unit.source: To write a string that runs a Windows PowerShell command, use the format:
trans-unit.target: To write a string that runs a Windows PowerShell command, use the format:

trans-unit.source: where the quotation marks indicate a string and the invoke operator (&) causes the command to be executed.
trans-unit.target: where the quotation marks indicate a string and the invoke operator (&) causes the command to be executed.

trans-unit.source: Shows this message.
trans-unit.target: Shows this message.

trans-unit.source: If you are typing a PowerShell.exe command in Windows PowerShell, prepend the command parameters with a hyphen (-), not a forward slash (/).
trans-unit.target: If you are typing a PowerShell.exe command in Windows PowerShell, prepend the command parameters with a hyphen (-), not a forward slash (/).

trans-unit.source: You can use either a hyphen or forward slash in Cmd.exe.
trans-unit.target: You can use either a hyphen or forward slash in Cmd.exe.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting Note: In Windows PowerShell 2.0, starting some programs in the Windows PowerShell console fails with a LastExitCode of 0xc0000142.
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting Note: In Windows PowerShell 2.0, starting some programs in the Windows PowerShell console fails with a LastExitCode of 0xc0000142.

trans-unit.source: EXAMPLES
trans-unit.target: EXAMPLES
